segments.text: get a significant pay raise for the teachers in the amount of 28.5% at the upper level.
It did take some convincing of the Senate when we got the conference committee to hold on to that amount.
What we were able to do did not help me much with the school teachers when I met with them after the session.
By 1981, the Texas State Teachers Association, which was the strongest arm of the teachers associations, Berkeley in Texas, had become aligned with the National Education Association.
New alignment was forced upon them by taking a succession of votes, I understand about four,
to join the National Education Association.

The first three votes that the Texas State Teachers Association took, I understand they turned down joining the National Education Association, and it wasn't until the fourth vote that they finally succumbed.
As a result, by 1981,
competing teachers association had emerged and the speaker's motive was to work with and help this association in its accomplishments during the session.
The speaker had not kept me informed on
his motives and strategy with regards to teacher pay.
And as a result, I had initially killed his proposal.
Chairman of the committee, I controlled the agenda and with a little finesse was able to bring the proposal back before the committee.
and get it passed for as much as a 28.5% increase, which the competing teachers association had requested.
The chairman of the senate conference committee was not predisposed to provide as much salary increase as the house had in its bill when we got to the conference committee.
But I was able to prevail upon the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee to accept the House proposal and provide for a larger teacher pay increase than was in the Senate bill.
I was naive enough to think that with my support on more than one occasion for a significant pay raise that I might stand in good stead with the Texas State Teachers Association.
but failed to take into account the rivalry that was taking place between the two competing associations, i.e.
the two lobby groups for the Texas teachers.
As a result, when it came time to make endorsements in my campaign for reelection in 1982, the Texas state teachers quickly endorsed my opponent.
In prior sessions of the legislature, I had to deal with the issue of how to get
in a timely manner for computers and computer upgrades needed to do research at our major research institutions.
Computers were first introduced in Texas state government.
The Appropriations Committee through the leadership of a previous chairman had
great difficulty in some of the decisions that some state agencies were making with regards to acquisition of computers.
As a result, riders were placed in the appropriations bill that made it rather cumbersome to acquire computers for state agencies.
In most cases, this was not a serious problem.
more of an inconvenience for those agencies.
However, in the case of major research institutions that were having to acquire computers and computer upgrades and software for research purposes, time was of the essence.

and found the process of having to get approval from both the Texas State Auditor and the Governor's Office too time consuming to get the research project underway as required by contract with the federal government.
struggling with this problem for several sessions, I asked for an interim committee to see if we could not come up with a better solution with regards to acquisition of computers.
I quickly learned that it was going to take more time than I had as a part-time legislator to negotiate the
that needed to be made.

The Speaker of the House recognized this and when he was approached by a former member of the legislature who happened to be a member of the Texas A&M University faculty and was leaving that post here at A&M, the Speaker contacted me and asked me if I would put him to work.
staffing this committee that had been appointed, that I was chairing.
I was delighted to do so, and Jack Woods, a former member of the Texas House from Waco, meeting with the state auditor and the governor's office on numerous occasions,
and keeping me advised of the progress that he was making.
He was able to negotiate a from them to a bill that would create a new state agency called the Automated Information System Advisory Council.
with appointments being made by the lieutenant governor, the governor, and the speaker.
The council would be advisory in nature.
It was constitutionally for the appointments to be made by the three principal officers in state government.
The Information System Advisory Council was made law by my House Bill 1463.
It was very favorably received by state agencies.
State agencies needed help.
in making acquisitions and found this new agency to be very helpful in getting the job done.
Certainly in later years, the council has been revamped and given more power and longer advisory in nature
This is unfortunate and I think has not been in the best interest of good government that now they have more power and are more intimidating to state agencies and as a result not near as helpful.
In 1982 during a special session
The legislature finally did away with the old 10 cent ad valorem tax that was used to fund state universities and colleges outside of the permanent university fund.
By then that the courts were going to rule that the
ad valorem tax at state level was unconstitutional because it was not being uniformly applied across the state.
School districts appraised their property values at extremely low rates while others were almost at true market value.
As a result, the ten cent tax being applied
to diverse rates going to cause the courts to rule the 10 cent tax unconstitutional.
I may have been responsible for this special session since you will recall that some two years prior to special session,

the governor had tried to convince me to back off of my opposition to a constitutional amendment at that time, which would have abolished the ten cent tax, which I had no problem with, but at the same time was giving Prairie View one-third of the permanent university fund.
vehemently opposed and was able to garner enough opposition votes to keep the constitutional amendment from getting the necessary 100 votes.
The special session of 1982, the governor was able to limit the

call that he placed on the legislature for the special session to subject matter that did not deal with the permanent university fund therefore we had a clear up-and-down vote on a constitutional amendment dealing with the ten-cent ad valorem tax was during this special session that for the first time we were
appropriating funds to a number of universities for construction directly from general revenue.
As chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, I found this quite frustrating and dramatic in that it was very difficult to evaluate

the need for various construction programs around the state as a member of the legislature who had not visited all of these facilities and did not have the expertise to evaluate one project against the other.
Politics became a major factor in deciding
who got the funds in that special session for construction projects.
There was another situation similar to the regular session in 1977 when the committee got out of hand.
was making appropriations that I did not think could stand scrutiny and would exceed our budget that we had set aside for these construction projects.
The outcome was quite different, however.
I was able to let the members add these items and then, as chairing the conference committee,
take the items out when we got to the conference committee level.
Some danger in waiting until the conference committee unless you've had an opportunity to look at the version of the same bill or companion bill that the Senate has passed.
It may not be an issue if it's both in the House bill and the Senate bill and would be very difficult to remove an item of this nature.
wish that I had had the genius that has been later reflected in the appropriations bill passed in 1993 where such items were moved to an article that was not funded.
The members were happy to be in the appropriations bill even though
funds were not guaranteed for the projects.
These were placed in 1993 in Article 11, and some received appropriations later in conference committee and some did not.
However, if no action was taken and they were left in Article 11, then they essentially fell out of the bill without having to take any action.
1982 was a re-election year that for the third time in my career I would have an opponent for re-election.
The opponent had been a previous employee of the College Station School District, had been active in the
local state senator's campaign to defeat a long-term incumbent and had gone to Austin to work on his staff during the regular session.
After the session was over, he returned to Brazos County and worked for a local newspaper distributor.
It was an interesting campaign in that my opponent had spent most of the regular session of 1981 in the House gallery keeping a tally of how I voted on various issues.
It seemed like almost every day he had a new issue and kept changing
the subject, so to speak, probably too often to have an effective campaign.
He was able to raise money from around the state but primarily from other states to fund his campaign quite adequately.
I think that the

opposition really did not expect me to work very hard since i had been in the legislature for a number of years and was chairing uh... the most important committee in the house did not spend as much time as i had in previous campaigns but did feel like that i could uh... still conduct a rather effective campaign on a part-time basis for the first time
I decided to run a poll but did not want to spend a lot of money bringing in a professional pollster.
I got some help from a professional pollster as to how to conduct a poll and with a few volunteers we were able to get enough information
to tell us that we were leading our opponent by about a two to one vote.
Poster suggested that if I had that kind of lead that I should simply ignore the attacks of my opponent and just ride it out until election day.
This is rather easy for a poster

to say but it's difficult to do when you've got members of your campaign staff who are volunteers and close friends that are out working for you saying you need to answer him and you need to be more aggressive in your
you're answering the opponent's attacks.

I decided to answer him in a very general way as to how easy it was for a challenger to raise all these issues when he was not there and was not having to make the decisions that I, as the office owner, had to make.
The polls, although not very scientific, did predict about how we were to come out in the race.
Although we lost a lot of the minority boxes, we ended up with about 65% of the vote in that primary of 1982.
Long about this time that the...
So my family and some friends got together and organized and chartered Commerce National Bank in College Station, Texas.
This was a national charter, but I did not think that the public would distinguish between
a national charter where a state politician would have no influence, and a state charter where a state politician could have considerable influence.
So I decided that I would not become a member of the original board of directors simply to downplay any political issues.
that might accrue because I was serving on a bank board.
It was later when I knew that I would be leaving the legislature that I became a member of the board of directors of Commerce National Bank and College Station.
In the summer of 1982, I decided to take off
for a 30-day period and study for the state bar exam to see if I could get my license to be a practicing attorney in Texas under an old law that had been passed many years prior with the
The number of years I had in service as a member of the Texas legislature, I could sit for the bar, and if I could pass the exams, I could become a licensed attorney.
Only about four or five members of the legislature had ever attempted to pass the bar in such a manner.
Of those that did ultimately pass the exam and was granted a license, all attended law school for a period of time, but did not complete all the requirements to finish law school.
developed that the Speaker of the House was studying for the bar at the same time and took the exam on the same day during that summer of 1982.
The Speaker had previously announced just a month or so prior to
the time we were studying for the bar that he would not be a candidate for a statewide elected office.
He had a rather extensive farming operation and had decided to expand that operation even more extensively and did not feel like that serving as a statewide elected official would be compatible with
his financial needs.
At the very last minute, he declined to become a candidate for the General Land Office.
1982 also
was a year that we had a race for Speaker of the House to replace Mr. Clayton.
My deskmate for a number of years, Gibb Lewis, was a leading candidate for Speaker.
I was not supporting it.
Some years before, I had pledged to support a friend of mine for Speaker if he ever chose to run.
And he had chosen to run and was opposing my deskmate for Speaker of the House.
when the election was held in January of 1983.
Mr. Lewis understood this, although he would have liked to have had my support.
But I appreciate the fact that he never pressured me in any way to gain my support for his candidacy.
It was late one Sunday evening.
when I received a call from this friend of mine who was opposing Gibb Lewis for the speakership.
And he told me that this candidacy for speaker had rapidly deteriorated the last couple of days.
I had been out of the state and wasn't sure what was going on, but sensed that the wave of support was going in Mr. Lewis's favor.
The Republican contingency in the House was lining up solidly behind Mr. Speaker.
our Mr. Lewis and would put him over the top for our speaker.
A friend who was opposing Mr. Lewis at the time suggested that I might want to call Mr. Lewis.
I hung up, the phone rang again and
On the other end was Gib Lewis, who was wanting to visit with me again about the speaker's race.
I told him that I had just been talking to Mr. Uher, his opponent, who I was supporting, and that I had been released of any commitment to him.
Mr. Lewis said that he would be in College Station the next day, and at that time I signed a pledge card to support him for Speaker.
I realized that I was getting on the late train and would probably not be back in 1983 as chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.
Later that year, when the speaker's race was all but over, I happened to be on a plane with Mr. Lewis, and we were flying to Corpus Christi.
This was the first indication that I had that I would be his appointee for chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.
The way he approached the subject, he asked me if I had any ideas about how I wanted to run the House Appropriations Committee next year.
I told him, as a matter of fact I did, that I felt like it was time to put the CBOs, the Chairman of Budgets and Oversights, of the various substantive committees on the Appropriations Committee.

This would do away with seniority in its entirety if the rules were written to put the CBOs on the committee, and this could be a problem to him politically and one that he would have to deal with before making that decision.
probably want to talk to some of the senior members that had supported him for Speaker before making that move.

A few weeks later he called me and we were talking and he told me that he had decided that was a good idea and that he would support that change in the rules that would put the CBOs on the Appropriations Committee.
The downside to this approach of composing the Appropriations Committee of CBOs was the fact that the number of members of the committee had to be expanded from 21 to 28.
The addition of seven additional members did make the committee rather cumbersome.
but in many ways caused a better information flow to the committee by having those that had heard detailed requests from the state agencies sitting on the Appropriations Committee.
A few days prior to the 1983 legislative session convening, my wife and I decided that we should for the first time take up residence in Austin during the session and move
family to Austin for the session.
We had one daughter who was then a high school student and had become involved in extracurricular activities and was having a medical problem that the doctors had been unable to diagnose.

by making the move would give her a clean break with all the high school activities and give her a chance to readjust to a slower lifestyle than she had found herself involved in in a large public high school.
We were able to locate an apartment
close to a church school, provided all 12 grades.
This proved to be good for our daughter since she did not have the hectic lifestyle and pace that she had created for herself in
at Bryan High School.
It was also good to be able to come home each evening and have my family there in Austin.
The election of Gibb Lewis, Speaker, and Lieutenant Governor Bill Hobby returning to his post, the two agreed that each Monday morning

They would have breakfast with the House Appropriations Committee, myself, Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Senator Jones, and the two chairmen of the State Affairs Committees, their respective houses.
The idea was to rotate the breakfast between the Speaker's apartment and the Lieutenant Governor's apartment each Monday morning.
After the breakfast meetings were convened, the Lieutenant Governor's apartment
was destroyed by fire, which almost cost the state, its entire state capital because of its construction had not been modernized to the fire from sweeping through the entire capital.
The fire was contained just in the Lieutenant Governor's office and apartment and caused them to vacate those facilities.
Bill Harvey did not live in the apartment himself, so there was no problem as far as quarters were concerned.
The consequence of the fire
The decision was made that the Monday morning breakfasts would be held in the speaker's quarters for the duration of the session.
These meetings were particularly helpful in developing a strategy for the session and in getting artists lined up
for the session.

The priorities of the House and the Senate do not always coincide, but it was good to know what the two houses were thinking and where there could be agreement and some resolution worked out on certain major issues.
It was partially as a result of one of those Monday morning breakfasts that I found myself going to the hospital and spending a few days for the first time since I was two years old.
This particular Monday morning, I had arisen a little earlier than usual and had coffee at the apartment with my wife.
I arrived at the Capitol ahead of everyone else but for the kitchen help in the Speaker's apartment.
I had time to drink another cup or two of coffee before the arrival of the Speaker, Lieutenant Governor, and the other legislators.
During breakfast, I unconsciously drank some more coffee, left the meeting and the House Appropriations Committee for a hearing on the appropriations request of the Texas A&M University System.
During the hearing, I
had time to drink another cup of coffee and the next thing I knew I was on my way to the hospital.
Took about three days in the hospital to determine that my heart was in good condition and that I had no problems.
One of the concerns the doctor had was that I had not had a
check up for quite some time and was not familiar with my history with regards to my heart.
It was finally determined that I did have a slight heart murmur, but it had been with me all of my life and was not anything to be concerned with.
With the exception of the three days I spent in the hospital, the time that I spent chairing the Appropriations Committee was rather pleasant that session.
The conditions was tight, but not extremely so.
The state's economy appeared to still be in good shape in early 1983.
And the revenue projections were adequate that we did not need to make any significant reductions.
The chair of the Budget and Oversight Committee did see fit to make 3% across the board reductions for all of higher education.
And with the exception of some of the
agencies within the Texas A&M University system did not create a serious problem.
It took some gentle persuasion and education on my part to convince the chairman of the Budget and Oversight Committee when he took a 3% reduction of the total appropriations of an agency that
was receiving only about ten percent of its appropriations from general revenue that he was cutting general revenue rather dramatically.
Once this was accomplished we were able to get the bill out of committee and into conference committee with some ease.
A major issue that the conference committee
had to deal with was the difference in appropriations methodology for some of the medical schools at MD Anderson in the University of Texas system.
The chairman of the Budget and Oversight Committee had reported that rather significant large sums
of unexpended balances existed within the medical school budgets of the University of Texas system.
And that there was no reason that we could not appropriate some of those funds and still allow them to do the things they wanted to do.
The University of Texas had
a different idea, but apparently decided to leave this issue until the conference committee met to work out the differences between the House and the Senate bills.
As we approached the deadline for finishing the conference committee report on one Sunday afternoon, this issue still remained one that
the House and the Senate conferees could not agree upon.
In the meantime, Lieutenant Governor Bill Hobby had come to the conference committee room and was beginning to work with his Senate conferees.
I immediately called the Speaker to
who was on the golf course, to come to the Capitol and help us resolve this issue.
We finally had to, by ourselves, from view of the public and the media, to have a frank discussion with regards to this issue.
The University of Texas officials convinced us that they could not live with the
reductions that the House made, but were willing to make some reductions in those unexpended balances by allowing us to appropriate them as a part to replace general revenue.
A decision was made as to what the amounts would be
that we would use from those unexpended balances in the health science centers.
We proceeded back to the appropriations committee room to reconvene the conference committee and take a formal and final vote on the issue.
This, by the way, was the only time that I can recall that the conference committee did, in fact, violate the rules and make a tentative decision in closed meeting.
It became an official meeting because all the conferees were present at the time the discussion took place.
The meeting was held in the Lieutenant Governor's office.
Reconvening the conference committee in the House Appropriations Committee room,
I made the motion that the amount that had been previously agreed to would be made a part of the Conference Committee report.
The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and the chairman of the Conference Committee took a vote with all five senators voting for the issue, while on the House side, I was the only
with the other four voting in the negative.
Totally surprised and appalled at the outcome of the vote, which meant that the issue was still unresolved.
Later explained to me that the other four conferees had left the

meeting in the Lieutenant Governor's office with the Speaker and they were still complaining about not appropriating what the House had originally put in this bill with regards to these unexpended balances.
The Speaker's response, I was told, was, well, do whatever you want to.
The other four house conferees agreed to vote against my motion.

The next morning I got the speaker to speak to the house conferees and tell them that we had to get this issue resolved and that they needed to vote for the amounts that had been agreed upon in Lieutenant Governor's office.
the only unresolved issue in the bill and we could not report the bill out and get it passed during the regular session if it was not resolved very quickly.
The Speaker agreed to speak to the other conferees and the issue was quickly resolved and for
Fourth time in a row, the biennial appropriations bill was passed with no new taxes, certified by the comptroller and signed into law.
